title: Consecration of Priests
shortSummary: Exodus 29 details the elaborate consecration ceremony for Aaron and his sons as priests, including offerings, anointing, and the sanctification of garments and the altar. This chapter establishes the sacred duties and perpetual priesthood ordained by God to mediate between Him and Israel.
timeline: c. 1446 BC - The Exodus, during the wilderness journey after leaving Egypt

keyCharacters.name: Aaron
keyCharacters.description: Brother of Moses and the first high priest, consecrated in this chapter to serve in the priestly office.

keyCharacters.name: Sons of Aaron
keyCharacters.description: Aaron's sons who are also consecrated as priests to serve alongside their father in ministering to God.

keyCharacters.name: Moses
keyCharacters.description: God's appointed leader who performs the consecration rituals for Aaron and his sons as instructed by God.

definitions.definition: A specially prepared oil used to consecrate and set apart priests and objects for holy service.
A sacrifice made to atone for unintentional sins, symbolizing purification and forgiveness.
An offering presented by waving it before the Lord as a sign of dedication and acceptance.
An offering lifted up as a sacred gift to the Lord, often given to the priests as their portion.

outline.heading: Preparation and Garment Dressing of Priests
outline.description: Instructions are given for the selection of unblemished animals and unleavened bread for the consecration. Aaron and his sons are washed and clothed with priestly garments symbolizing holiness and readiness to serve God.

outline.heading: Consecration Sacrifices and Rituals
outline.description: The detailed sacrificial procedures include the laying on of hands, the killing of the bullock and rams, the application of blood on the altar and priests, and the burning of specific parts. These rites sanctify Aaron and his sons, setting them apart for their sacred duties.

outline.heading: Eating the Consecration Meal and Seven-Day Consecration
outline.description: Aaron and his sons eat the consecration ram and bread as a sign of fellowship with God. The seven-day period of consecration emphasizes the thorough sanctification required before entering priestly service.

outline.heading: Daily Offerings and Sanctification of the Altar
outline.description: God commands continual daily offerings of lambs with accompanying flour, oil, and wine to maintain atonement and sanctify the altar. God's promise to dwell among Israel and meet them at the tabernacle underscores His presence and covenant relationship.

application: Approach God with reverence and holiness, recognizing the importance of being set apart for His service as modeled by the priests' consecration.
Understand the significance of sacrifice and atonement in maintaining a right relationship with God, applying Christ’s ultimate sacrifice as fulfillment.
Commit to continual spiritual dedication and renewal, just as the altar required daily offerings to remain holy.
Embrace the privilege of God's presence by living in obedience and faithfulness, knowing He desires to dwell with His people.

keyVerses.text: And thou shalt gird them with girdles, Aaron and his sons, and put the bonnets on them: and the priest's office shall be theirs for a perpetual statute: and thou shalt consecrate Aaron and his sons.
keyVerses.significance: This verse establishes the perpetual nature of the Aaronic priesthood, emphasizing God's enduring covenant and the sacred office.

keyVerses.text: And thou shalt take of the blood that is upon the altar, and of the anointing oil, and sprinkle it upon Aaron, and upon his garments, and upon his sons, and upon the garments of his sons with him: and he shall be hallowed, and his garments, and his sons, and his sons' garments with him.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the sanctification process through blood and anointing oil, symbolizing purification and divine appointment.

keyVerses.text: This shall be a continual burnt offering throughout your generations at the door of the tabernacle of the congregation before the LORD: where I will meet you, to speak there unto thee.
keyVerses.significance: God’s promise to meet His people at the tabernacle underscores His desire for ongoing fellowship and communication with Israel.

keyVerses.text: And they shall know that I am the LORD their God, that brought them forth out of the land of Egypt, that I may dwell among them: I am the LORD their God.
keyVerses.significance: This verse affirms God's identity as deliverer and His commitment to dwell with His people, central to Israel’s faith and hope.
